deliverables: SAP-009 v1.1.0 with bidirectional translation protocol specification
Implementation in scripts/translate-bidirectional.py with ≥80% test coverage
Unit tests in tests/test_translate_bidirectional.py covering all translation modes
Integration tests validating round-trip translation accuracy
CHANGELOG.md entry documenting v1.1.0 changes and migration path
Performance benchmarks demonstrating <100ms translation time for typical artifacts
CLI tool supporting both directions: chora → standard, standard → chora
Updated AGENTS.md with bidirectional translation capabilities
acceptance_criteria: SAP-009 v1.1.0 specification includes complete protocol for both translation directions
Unit tests cover all 6 translation modes (3 directions × 2 formats)
Integration tests validate 100% round-trip accuracy for sample artifacts
CHANGELOG.md follows Keep a Changelog format with all breaking changes documented
Documentation clarity review achieves ≥85% score (5 reviewers)
Performance benchmarks show <100ms translation time for 95th percentile
CLI tool provides --help, --direction, --format flags with clear usage examples
AGENTS.md update reviewed and approved by ≥2 ecosystem contributors
Release v1.1.0 tagged and pushed to GitHub with complete release notes

context.background: SAP-009 currently supports one-way translation from chora-specific delimiters to standard Jinja2 delimiters. Ecosystem feedback indicates strong need for bidirectional translation to enable agents to work with both chora-base templates and standard template libraries. This prescriptive request defines the complete implementation scope for SAP-009 v1.1.0, including specification updates, implementation, testing, documentation, and release.
context.rationale: We considered three approaches: (1) extend existing translate.py with reverse mode, (2) create separate bidirectional script, (3) implement as independent package. Extending existing script creates confusion about translation direction. Independent package adds maintenance overhead. We chose a new bidirectional script with clear direction flags, enabling explicit control and better error messages while maintaining backward compatibility with existing one-way translation workflows.
